com.sri.ai.grinder.helper

Class BruteForceFallbackQuantifierEliminationStepSolver

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.sri.ai.grinder.helper.FallbackQuantifierEliminationStepSolver
      • com.sri.ai.grinder.helper.BruteForceFallbackQuantifierEliminationStepSolver
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ExpressionLiteralSplitterStepSolver, ExpressionStepSolver, LiteralSplitterStepSolver<Expression>, StepSolver<Expression>, java.lang.Cloneable

    @Beta
public class BruteForceFallbackQuantifierEliminationStepSolver
extends FallbackQuantifierEliminationStepSolver
    Wraps a base SingleQuantifierEliminationStepSolver into another one that solves the problem by brute force when the base one cannot.
    Author:
    braz

      • clone

        public BruteForceFallbackQuantifierEliminationStepSolver clone()
        Description copied from interface: StepSolver
        Cloning is important for this interface, because when a problem depends on an expression to be solved the StepSolver.ItDependsOn solver step will carry within it two sub-step solvers to be used on the two branches of the search (one for when the expression is enforced to be true, and another for false).

        While it is correct to just re-use the step solver returning the StepSolver.ItDependsOn object, it would then wastefully check again for all the expressions that had already been enforced true or false by the context. By allowing a step solver to clone itself, we are able to provide sub-step solvers that already know when to continue the search from.

        Note also that, instead of clone, we could have a copy constructor or just regular constructors receiving state information as parameters. However, clone provides more flexibility if one is writing code that manipulates StepSolvers in general, and therefore needs a way to create copies without knowing its actual class.

        Finally, it is recommended that the implementation of clone be the code below unless there is a good reason for doing otherwise. It may be more elegant to simply create a clone with one of the class's constructors, but this will require extensions of that class to override this method, whereas the version below will be reusable by extensions. If a different choice is made, the new cloning method should check if the instance is not that of an extension, or it should be very clearly documented, or the class should be made final.

        Specified by:
        clone in interface ExpressionLiteralSplitterStepSolver
        Specified by:
        clone in interface ExpressionStepSolver
        Specified by:
        clone in interface StepSolver<Expression>
        Overrides:
        clone in class FallbackQuantifierEliminationStepSolver
        Returns:
        a clone of this step solver.
